summary: A tough detective (Denzel Washington) matches wits with a cunning bank robber (Clive Owen), as a tense hostage crisis is unfolding. Into the volatile situation comes a woman named Madaline (Jodie Foster), a mysterious power broker who has a hidden agenda and threatens to push a tense situation past the breaking point.

reviews.content:
One of my favourite films of all time. Fantastic cast, filmography and twisty plot (my favourite kind).
My family hate watching films with me because, most of the time, I work out storylines, even unexpected ones, very early on in the process. However, Inside Man leads you down a path of prediction (i.e. the not-so-obvious conclusion), then suddenly the plot twists and you have to re-think your whole theory. 
Mine changed several times during the film as it slowly drip-fed new information to the audience. Then, when it did reveal its very satisfying reveal conclusion, it still went that little bit further and provided another little twist at the very end. 
Love it. I have even enjoyed watching it several times since with people who have never seen it before by being entertained watching them trying to work out the plot. 
Thoroughly recommend.
A very re-watchable movie with top talent doing what they do.
What's not to like about this film? Inside Man is a beautifully made thriller with several plot twist and top of the class acting, simple put it's la crème de la crème of crime films.
Loved this movie. I did not see that coming.

It's not always this weird returning to movies from the mid 00's and I think that says something about Inside Man. While it is technically a fascinating way to spin a heist movie - timeline hopping a little with an actually unusual and unpredictable heist - it comes off as feeling smarter, funnier, and more clever than it actually is. This is one of Spike Lee's few true blockbuster movies and I think he does a pretty good imitation of a blockbuster, but it in the end feels like it isn't entirely honest with itself and ultimately ends up feeling lost in the weeds of its own making.
I have no idea how this movie has so many good reviews. It isl rife with stereotypes, clichés and pointless dialogue. i've never seen so many award-winning actors in such a boring pointless venture.
Clive Owen was fantastic.   Other than that very average, was expecting more with the cast.   Unless you are bored, much better options

This movie takes the crime/heist genre and allows you to slowly makes you believe that this is going to be your run of the mill movie but then spins it on its head. When you have Denzel, you know your movie has a great chance to be great and they nailed it.
Stellar casts, good story plot.

Good story but the movie did not need to be two hours. With the star-studded cast, the dialogue, although funny and clever in places, could have been crisper; scenes could have been shorter to keep the pace moving and fun. Denzel was great. He saves the film's loooong middle searching for the punch line.    Spike Lee gets a B- for directing.
One of Denzel's best films, and the supporting cast is great too. Difficult to rate tgd plot without a spolier-alert.
I'm a huge fan of director Spike Lee & and actor Denzel Washington,  however I personally found INSIDE MAN to be one of the most disappointing films in both men's filmographies. C-

Outstanding plot, Clive Owen, and Denzel Washington make this the best non overly serious heist film out there. To expand, Heat and Heist are overly serious, Ocean's 11 and Bandits are full heist-comedy. Inside Man is an extremely happy medium.
Some of Denzel’s best work. Sadly they cancelled the sequel which I think takes away from the somewhat lack of resolution in this one. Still a great movie
Well-written, great cast/acting, stylish direction, an instant classic heist film.
A masterpiece. Some of the visual and audio techniques in this film elevate cinema as a whole, truly fantastic from beginning to end.
Good movie and script. Everything in the movie is made incredibly and simply.

Spike Lee is at his most mainstream with this clever and entertaining heist thriller. It doesn't really thrill all that much, and the payoff is underwhelming to say the least. And this being a Spike Lee film, there has to be a racial subtext. Still, the performances crackle with nice casting, with everyone taking their cue from a sturdy workmanlike Denzel in the lead. The pacing is fluid for most of the time, but the musical score feels off at times. Too bad this didn't meet the pot-boiler expectations its previews had promised
Spike Lee's Grade-A directing makes this a thriller that will keep you on your toes.
This was good, and very original. That said, I realized part way though that I had seen it before, yet didn't remember it at all, so maybe that says something?

Inside Man is actually a quite refreshing and different take on a bank heist film.  The standouts here are of course Denzel Washington as Keith Frazier and Clive Owen as our antagonist of sorts, Dalton Russell.  While not fantastic, it still does it's job to surprise and entertain us.
real good; smart plot & a great twist. & what a fantastic cast - Clive, Denzel, & Jody - they all fit their characters SO well. very well done. 10/10 would recommend.
Good, fun, entertaining movie. Some questionable writing/dialogue, but if anything you'd added to the fun. Worth a watch

I wholeheartedly agree with Walsh’s review here. Like he said, audiences have come to expect so little these days that mediocre tripe like this gets good reviews. The police and hostages in this disaster of a film are all standard Spike Lee stereotypes, which populate his tribal (Walsh) conception of New York City. And that ridiculous, pounding soundtrack was laughably melodramatic and added nothing to the film.

One of the best movies Ive seen in a while
and one of the best action movies I have ever seen
its must watch
 great performance from the actors
just wow

With the exception of a few stylishly executed shots, a New York locale and a brief social commentary about race, Inside Man is probably one of director Spike Lee's most ‘unSpike-like' films in his oeuvre.  Detective Keith Frazier (Denzel Washington) is assigned to handle a bank robbery in progress involving hostages.  Dalton (Clive Owen), the ringleader of the heist, has orchestrated the perfect crime and confidently manages his accomplices and hostages to ensure its success.  And then there is Madaline (Jodie Foster), a mysterious fixer who inserts herself into the drama.  Inside Man is a clever, well-executed thriller featuring strong performances from the entire cast and a plot that will keep audiences guessing until the final scene.
I found the plot confusing at times with holes you could run a bus through.

Movie about a robbery with a very well thought out plot and a really very nice development, it lacks a bit of tension to the viewer, but it compensates for it with a strong entertainment that keeps you glued to the screen
It's an event movie lacking the depth of characterisation required for such a premise. Tonally it's a mixed bag as well.

Look... the movie is pretty fun but watching films with oh-so-in-your-face casual misogyny is really annoying. I guess it's accidentally important as it reflects the attitude of filmmakers and writers at the time that it's being filmed. (2006) 

But that doesn't forgive it, just like all social injustices it needs to be pointed at and acknowledged. 

Also... often the detective dismisses, ignores, and interrupts important aspects of the investigation in order to engage in some swaggy dialogue. It's consistent, annoying, and unrealistic. 

The way he attacks nobodys in the interrogation center is totally ridiculous and unprofessional ... and FFS that soft-focus vaseline lens.
Denzel the guy just makes the best movies a must watch..
A good suspenseful intelligent heist movie with a nice cast and interesting twists. worth watching.
Good story, great cast, suspenseful, enjoyable. Hard to fault.

This is absolutely one of the best in the crime genre. Too bad the cast didn't have more time, because seeing them work was worth the cost of admission. To believe the pace is slow might denote a slowness in the critic, or perhaps just a mild retardation. Brilliant.

A bit too much on the interviews & flash backs, overall brilliant production. It's all about chasing out the skeleton from the closet. Solid casts orchestrate what the eyes saw the heart believe illusions trick.

My main issue with this movie was how illogical it all was. The first half is fine, yet the second half seems like a whole different movie. Lots of (what turn out to be) red herrings which make no sense at all, and what about Denzel's repeated talk about Big Willie and the Twins?
If you can endure Owen's horrendous American accent to get through to the end of the film, you will be disappointed. Worst heist film I've seen.
Film has really good pacing and plot is interesting

85%. Not much action or violence but a cool plot and much more than just a bank heist. It goes a lot deeper and the story as to why it's happening is great. The detective work by Denzel is awesome. Great heist movie but not quite on the town's level

15 years after the first watching, what a good heist thriller this is! I hope that somewhere in film colleges one takes this as an example of how to make a heist film that's functioning great: from the superb cast (Denzel Washington, Clive Owen, Jodie Foster, Christopher Plummer), and a script that's far from clichéd, to being able to make the viewer think while at the same time being very entertaining. Some of the scenes will seem very current, since the hostages have to wear the same kind of masks as the bank robberies, so it's impossible to distinguish them. In addition, I was pleased to see a film in which a corrupt multi-billion bank owner gets a payback. A recommendation without the doubt.

It's an intriguing enough and overall good movie, but very underwhelming. Considering the reviews, I was expecting an exhilarating heist thriller. But it didn't live up to that, it's actually quite different that your typical heist movie. It's got its moments, it's got a few little twists and turns here and there, but in the end, it feels too safe and it could've been way more thrilling. 
But on the bright side, it features a good score, which helps to wrap up some tension, and the film is supported by a terrific cast. We've got Christopher Plummer, Jodie Foster, Willem Dafoe, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Clive Owen and the great Denzel Washington to top it all off. 
Overall, Inside Man divided me a bit. It's a surely flawed pic, but still satisfying . It's no The Town (2010), but it still has a few things to offer. It just wasn't exactly the flick I was expecting. 
Recommended for genre fans.

It was alright 
Great cast but lacking in thrills and it's too long
Not just your average heist movie but a captivating thriller with various intriguing plots meeting up, supported by solid performances of its great cast.

This is the ultimate heist movie! I had seen at least some parts before, but couldn't remember the details of the plot, which made it more entertaining to watch! It has interesting cinematography, intelligent writing, and really great acting by Clive Owen, Denzel Washington, and Jodie Foster. I think the sound mixing had room for improvement - we had to keep turning the volume up and down during different types of scenes and the music felt out of place. Anyways, I would recommend it to anyone who has not seen it!
My favorite movie of all time. Think i have seen it at least 50+ times. Fantastic story and actor-performances all throughout the movie. My favorite line: 'Anyone else here smarter than me?!'. Great!
Great movie, great plot and plot twist, great actors. Watched it many times.

Inside Man is probably the most commercial film ever made by Spike Lee. It's a fun entertaining crime heist thriller with incredible actors such as Denzel Washington, Clive Owen, Jodie Foster, and others. The script is well written with an intriguing plot that keeps us intriguing and asking for more ending with an interesting twist. Denzel kills it as he always does immersing himself in the role and commanding the film. Clive Owen is also spectacular who always brings its sense of wit to his performances although here he is sometimes limited by a mask. Jodie Foster as a secondary character also shines with a character that has ulterior motives. The film has some political undertones which are universal in Lee's films but here there not too on the nose. He brilliantly directs this film and gives a fun popcorn flick that's well directed, acted, and scripted.
Very good movie.  A unique plot with a lot of suspense.

An above average bank heist film that shows multiple sides of the story with a few twists. The acting was good, but a few characters could have been better and didn't serve much purpose (e.g. the lawyer). The plot felt somewhat fresh due to the alternating between the detectives/police and bank robbers. It was also borderline believable, although I doubt the escape route would have worked in reality. However, the cinematography and soundtrack were nothing special. The police interview scenes should've looked better and like the rest of the film rather than having a tinted/grainy appearance. On the other hand, the visual effects were all right. Nothing was great, but it wasn't bad.
Spike Lee and his A++ cast nail this multifaceted caper flick and make it easy to stay engaged, even on subsequent viewings. 7.5/10
One of the better bank robbery movies in crowded field
Realistic, which makes movies like this fun to watch. Good acting, wasn’t great considering the cast, but story itself makes it a great movie.
one of the best caper movies.  never a dull moment.

This is a smart, well-executed heist movie. It's constantly letting the audience know that it's going to pull a fast one at the end, but keeps them guessing who and when and how. The top tier actor list does not disappoint, bringing the rich characters to life with a smooth aggressiveness that makes full use of their considerable talents. The pacing would normally be considered slow-burn, but there's enough to think about at all times that the pauses instead become room to think and let the plot breathe a little. Ultimately it thinks it's a bit more clever than it actually is and it takes too long to wrap up in the third act, but those are small criticisms for such a unique and well thought out story.

Closest comparison: It's like Heist (2001) mixed with Silence of the Lambs, but with drama and intrigue in place of psychological horror.

Setting: Detective
Plot: Heist
Tone: Drama
I loved this movie. I love heist movies in the first place and this was one of the better heist movies I’ve ever seen. The cast is fantastic and the story was great. I would recommend to anyone!

Good splice story. Bank heist with a hostage situation to it and there's more to it than initially meets the eye!

Denzel doing what he does best and a solid performance from Owen throughout.

Probably wouldn't rush to watch again, not a groundbreaking movie, but definitely worth the watch.

It's not among Spike Lee's best works, but it's an engaging bank heist thriller, with a smart and witty script, an energic pace, and unexpected plot twists that keep the narrative fresh and entertaining.
Pretty good bank heist thriller.
Loved it, the way the characters interacted in a way that showed intelligence and planning was interesting and led to complex scenarios and unique situations.

It was ok. Ngl, I expected more than... well, I won't say. It had its moments and Denzel was great. I thought it tried to be more clever than it actually was and felt a bit pretentious at times. Yeah, it was ok. I guess
Strong performances and some twits as well. If you like heist films this might be a must watch.

To anyone that suggests that Spike Lee is incapable of producing films that rely too heavily on racial commentary, Inside Man is a solid counter. It's laden with twists to the point where many become painfully obvious from a substantial distance, but is overall an enjoyable heist film that features an all-star cast, even if certain talent (Ejiofor and Dafoe) feel almost criminally underused. Is it destined to become a classic in the genre, or appear as a defining performance for any of its actors? Probably not, but you can pop it on during a weekday night and go to sleep satisfied. (3.5/5)
Great performances and I considered a 4/5, but the ending didn't do credit to the rest of the film and it kind of dragged as it tries to tie up and chase down every loose end.

Overall, a very good film that holds your interest.  clive and Denzel and Jodi are great. However, it features one of the most glaring blunders at the end - spoiler alert -

How in the world are all the thieves not descendants of the man whose home/possessions were stolen by the nazis?  Huge, gaping flaw.

Classic story line but stellar cast brings it home. Foster's character is a bit muddled but you forgive it amongst stronger leads. Good twists with a satisfying ending, could be excellent if it had stronger connection between characters and their story lines.
Pretty slow burn but the acting and the ending make up for it. A twist no one saw coming. Solid movie
I don't know if it's Spike Lee's best movie but unlike the rest, it's the most rewatchable. I've probably watched it 15 times and have only watched Do The Right Thing once
I was expecting a spectacular heist movie but I got a good one instead. The cast was good, so were the plot, the conversations, the directing even the music but it wasn't great as I wanted it to be.

One of the best heist films ever made.  The thing about casting Denzel in this role is that you expect him to be very intelligent and able to go toe-to-toe with the master criminal, even though the early part of the film really did not set him up as a super cop.  The back and forth between him and Clive Owen really makes the film and helps maintain the pacing.  Jodie Foster adds a wonderful side story to the movie, keeping the movie from being boring by being one dimensional.

I'm not sure how I feel about this movie. Usually, if I finish watching a movie and still don't understand a central part of what the plot turns on, it irritates the heck out of me. I started searching for articles explaining it and ... most of the articles out there that were like "let me explain the brilliant plot twist!" didn't understand it either, or at least didn't have a *full* explanation that was satisfying and made sense -- particularly in terms of the motive for the whole thing. (Part of the twist becomes pretty clear by the end, but the bigger story and rationale behind that twist remains very unclear.) And then I finally found a comment thread that made it all fall into place... and if this theory is correct, one of the central figures in the plot is a minor character with a tiny number of lines. Which is kind of an interesting move. Thinking about it later made me think about the movie in terms of primitive accumulation and the ill-gotten sources of most fortunes. But maybe there's also a commentary here on the difficulty and partiality of accountability for the wrongs of the past.
Ultimately encompassing one too many dramatic reveals and "1, 2, 3, cue the music!" moments.

From director Spike Lee comes the smart and intense crime thriller Inside Man.  When a group of bank robbers take hostages and lock themselves in a bank NYPD detective Keith Frazier is sent in to negotiate, but things soon take a strange turn when the bank's owner calls in a specialist to negotiate privately with the robbers on his behalf.  Starring Denzel Washington, Clive Owen, Jodie Foster, Christopher Plummer, Willem Dafoe, and Chiwetel Ejiofor, the film features an impressive cast that delivers some strong performances (particularly Clive Owen).  And Lee too does a good job at heightening the tension and at setting a foreboding tone.  Additionally, the script is especially well-written, particularly in how it sets up the heist and buildings intrigue by using flash-forwards of interviews with the hostage about what happened in the bank during the robbery.  Dramatic and exciting, Inside Man is a fresh take on the heist genre.

One of the best movie by Spike Lee. Plan and implementation of the "perfect robbery" all seasoned by the usual, wonderful and romantic cross-section of New York (and America in general) so dear to the director in any of his works. Excellent direction (which also grants some finesse at a technical level with highly sought after shots and sequence shot), excellent editing. Good acting.
Overall, Lee succeeds in creating a gripping and original heist thriller, but cringy humor and unlikeable characters unfortunely drag the movie away from real acclaim.

Spike Lee has never been known for his subtlety as Get on the Bus (1996) could be accused of literally spelling out it's message to you but his mid-2000s work has received praise for being more accessible. This film in particular is a clear attempt at making a mainstream, commercially successful product with occasional references to racial tension to ensure that the critics are pleased. I wanted to go with the film but it's plot was so preposterous that it was hard to care and the smugness with which the film went about it's business turned me off completely. Most heist thrillers are similarly ridiculous but this film had none of the introspection of Rififi (1955) or the emotional depth of Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007).

Dalton Russell, Clive Owen, attempts to rob a bank in Manhattan with the help of masked accomplices as he forces those inside the building to wear costumes and locks them in various rooms. The case is investigated by Detective Joe Frazier, Denzel Washington, with the help of Detective Bill Mitchell, Chiwetel Ejiofor, who is confused by the responses of those trapped inside the building. Complicating matters further is the fact that independent contractor Madeleine White, Jodie Foster, is determined to ensure that a safe deposit box does not have it's contents discovered. She works for the mysterious owner of the bank, Arthur Case, Christopher Plummer, whose possessions are inside in the safe deposit box and he refuses to tell her exactly what is inside the box. A late breaking twist turns our understanding of events on it's head.

Sadly the lead up to this twist drags on for far too long to hold our interest and the twist itself is disappointing as there are so many obvious plot holes that you can't help feeling cheated. Why would Case have kept the incriminating document and the diamonds? Who is White and what are her motivations? Not to mention the fact that the security cameras should have captured those in the bank before the robbery. Films that invest us enough in their concept during the first half are generally capable of shocking us with a twist but because I was never engaged it landed with a thud. Lee's execution of the reveal was also awkward as we see the opening scene of Owen speaking smugly to camera before he reveals information that comes out of field. We are angered as the film has set up it's premise as though the information he has provided us with would allow us to understand the ending but this is not true at all. When the out of nowhere twist arrives it has little relation to what we have learnt so there is no cleverness to the set up and it isn't gratifying.

The chaotic shooting style that Lee adopts also hinders the film rather than raising it above the average film within it's genre. When they witness the various hostages inside the bank getting dragged around or Frazier rushing around outside we get over the top camerawork that confuses the audience rather than involving them in the events occurring. I wanted to feel excitement as a group of hostages in jumpsuits screamed and various guns were pressed against various temples but I felt a surprising amount of apathy despite the considerable violence on displaying. The leery attitude that Lee takes towards women was also on display as all women were either sex objects or old, overweight women to be mocked. One hostage played by Kim Director has her breasts ogled by both Frazier and Mitchell but Lee seems to be reveling in the sexism rather than commenting on it and encouraging his audience to enjoy in viewing a woman only as a niece hunk of cleavage. Even Foster is often viewed as a sex object despite the supposedly powerful position she holds and it was disappointing to consider that despite making so many films Lee had not progressed as a filmmaker.

The performances all felt off as Foster in particular didn't seem to have a real sense of what register to play her character at. She was neither deliciously campy villain nor quietly commanding shadowy figure and although I wanted to hate her as you do a great villain I felt at a strange remove from her. This let a lot of the tension out of the film and I couldn't partake in the glee of seeing her cut down at the end of the film.

An entertaining play on heist tropes.

Spike Lee's crime thriller Inside Man (2006) is a frenzy of fun heist sequences with great planning and clever writing. Inside Man plays with the very idea of what a heist is and how it can be carried out over the course of a film. Lee's direction is solid as he keeps you looking where he wants, so that you never guess the twists and turns of Inside Man. 

The cinematography is good, but not the greatest among Lee's films. The lighting is oddly dark and the shots are just generally ugly looking or dated. The pace slows down towards the middle as there's too much fat spent on long interview sequences with the hostages awkwardly edited into action sequences. I understand why these clips are placed there, but they are not well executed like the heist parts themselves. Spike Lee could have trimmed Inside Man down to have a more focused vision.

Denzel Washington is gripping as he desperately tries to negotiate with the bank robbers to save the lives of numerous hostages. Washington delivers a killer performance of gravitas and wisdom. His character is always catching up even when a step behind. Clive Owen makes for an intimidating bank robber as he brilliantly pulls off an intricate heist like few other crime movies. His strong leadership and undeniable presence makes Inside Man all the more unpredictable in nature as anything can happen with a precise criminal in charge.

I really enjoy Jodie Foster's performance as the tough and resourceful mercenary brought in to help mediate between the bank robbers and the police. She's quick-witted and intelligent as Foster gives a steadfast performance as the manipulative and graceful fixer. I just wish Spike Lee would have used her in more of the film. She's introduced early on, has a few scenes in the middle, then is only there again for the second to last scene. What a waste of a genius actress.

I like Willem Dafoe's police chief, but he only gets a few choice lines and interesting moments. Dafoe should have been given more to do, especially since Chiwetel Ejiofor is fun, but also gets nothing to do. Dafoe and Ejiofor are outshined by Denzel in every scene. Washington is just more magnetic and commanding of a force. Lastly, Spike Lee completely wasted Christopher Plummer, who does a great job seeing as he's given only a few lines, but he could have been a more present figure. He's there to meddle, but he is never overbearing or mysterious truly. The reveal about his character should have prompted a bigger reaction, but everyone is fairly unconcerned or unbothered by such a shocking revelation.

Finally, Terence Blanchard's jazz score is excellent as per usual from Blanchard. I hear echoes of melodies he would later use for BlacKKKlansman with Spike Lee already. Blanchard's jazz has style, class, and energy. I'm glad he composed a fantastic score for Inside Man to up the ante of every scene's suspense.

In short, Spike Lee did a commendable job directing Inside Man, but it's not his best movie. Malcolm X and Do the Right Thing are far more inspired films compared to the above average thriller Inside Man.
As good as it gets when it comes to bank robbery movies.
It's a little flat in places. It's not as good as The Town. But I was satisfied.

A few sparkling moments joined by cornball dialogue. A brilliant premise failed by distracting camera work that offers nothing to the scene. And WOW the image this paints of women overall: scheming or stupid or whores. Once again, Spike Lee plays the race card so un-subtly, it loses its impact. Lee just never addresses race relations with depth or detail -- in this film the racial missteps by characters could be replaced with them barfing.
A smart crime movie that has pretty good plot. Ya their is are tiny plot hole here and there, but most of them can be overlooked. If your a fan of bank heist movies then this a movie for you.
Really enjoyed this movie.
Great movie. Flawless. One of the Best heist of all time beside the Thomas Crown's affair 1999.

Inside Man is not your standard cops and robbers movie. It so much smarter, original, and vastly more complex. It's a brilliant thriller and crime drama that takes the usually formula in ways you'd never expect. It's a fascinating battle of wills. And it even brings some moral depth along the way.

To say that Inside Man has a twisting plot would be a vast understatement. This is the kind of movie where absolutely nothing is as it seems, no-one can be trusted, and everything you think you know is probably wrong. Not only is the bad guy's plan complex beyond belief, but there are so many players with their own, often inscrutable agendas. This movie keeps you- and most of its characters- guessing almost till the end. The whole thing is brilliant and confounding on the level of The Usual Suspects, although with a less ambiguous ending.

And what an ending it is. It's the kind of blow you away twist that you'll never see coming, but that will instantly make sense and cast the entire story so far in a new light. And amazingly, the movie doesn't stop there, but takes the time to wrap up every dangling plot thread and provide full closure. Normally this would feel like the film had missed its exit cue, but here it works, and brings the film to an even more satisfying conclusion.

As Dalton Russel, Clive Owen is a criminal mastermind on the level of Kaiser Soze. When he says he planned the perfect heist, he is not exaggerating one bit. He has every detail planned out, and every possibility covered. At every step of the way he's ahead of the cops. And by the end, when you begin to understand his full motives, you want him to get away with it. Despite having his face covered in most of his scenes, he radiates a keen intelligence, and the calm smugness of someone who knows he has everyone where he wants them. Which makes his occasional bursts of violence even more shocking. I would call him one of Hollywood's best villains in years, except that I'm not sure if he's really a villain.

Denzel Washington is also in full form as Detective Keith Frazier. Intellectually, he may not be on the same level as Russel. But he's smart enough to know when he's being played, and to admit what he doesn't know. Which in this case is far too much for his liking. But even without a full understanding of the situation, or the game his opponent is playing, he (mostly) knows what he's doing, and usually makes the right calls. His battle of wits with Russel is absolutely fascinating; like De Niro and Pacino in Heat, only with higher stakes and less margin for error.

With his calm, steady, and often surprisingly friendly demeanor, he's quite relatable, and his attempts to figure out just what the hell is going on mirror our own. But he's at his very best in the interview/interrogation scenes. With each of the witnesses and suspects Denzel goes the full range from friendly and sympathetic to intense and accusatory, while dropping in bits of frustration, weariness, and some great jokes too. And in the end, he brings a real smoothness and swagger that I'm sure owe a fair amount to Spike Lee's direction.

Jodie Foster is excellent as well in role of high-powered fixer Ms. White. We don't see as much of her as we do Denzel and Owen, but in every scene, she exudes a deep confidence and intelligence, combined with a willingness to do whatever it takes to get the job done. She's effortlessly manipulative and almost charmingly coy even as she's infuriatingly smug and aloof. Yet you can't shake the feeling that she has more of a conscience than she let's on. Although she plays her cards very close to her chest, we know what she's after from the beginning. The fun is figuring out how she's going to get it, and what that means for the other players.

In addition to the great performances and excellent screenplay, Inside Man is a superbly well directed movie. Spike Lee keeps the pacing tight and the suspense almost unrelenting. There's some very effective use of flashbacks and flash forwards to mix things up and better process what we've seen so far. Every scene is perfectly lit and composed, unless it's supposed to be obscured and grainy. While this isn't exactly an action movie per se, there are some very good action sequences and impressive pyrotechnics towards the end. And because this is a Spike Lee joint, there's a good amount of New York flavor despite the confined setting, and even hints of the city's racial tensions and civil liberties issues.

If there's any flaw or shortcoming to this movie, I'm at a loss for what it would be. Even the opening and closing credits are brilliant in their own offbeat way. Inside Man is tense, edge of your seat excitement from beginning to end, and far smarter than your average thriller.

One of the best bank heist thriller I have come across, its focus on solid plot, many twists, fast pace, and smart humor makes it an entertaining watch. The superb casting and their performances only add to the charms of the movie.
One of my favorate movies . One scene pulls away from the tension of yhr film being the scene about the foreign language and decifering that but other than that astounding movie
Acting was as professional as you would expect from that great cast. What I missed were characters and a solid climax. But overall a fun movie for a Saturday evening.

Great movi that grabs your attention from the beginning and doesn't let it go! Clive Owen and Denzel Washington do a terrific job portraying their characters on this smart, fun and energetic bank heist movie.
Well-directed, tense, and well-written by Russell Gewirtz with slick dialogue and a good story and has a great performance by Denzel Washington. Probably my favorite Spike Lee movie.

Whilst Owen's, Foster's and Plummer's performances are strong, the script for this film creates two arrogant, unintelligent and ultimately unlikeable protagonists. "Inside Man" is not a story that I would expect to be told by Spike Lee.  He steps away from his typical racial themes to give us a lesson in deception.  This unique crime thriller intersperses police interviews with flashbacks of the bank robbery in question.  At first, the out of context interviews do not make much sense.  As the story progresses, the flashbacks give meaning to the interviews until the end reveals that... all of our assumptions were wrong!  The film alludes to (and even directly shows) how these criminals will pull off this heist, but you will still be completely shocked in the end.  You have to love a story that successfully turns the bank robbers into heroes and the cops into bad guys.  The intentionally convoluted story is supported by big-name actors who all live up to their reputations.  Clive Owen is truly terrifying as the criminal mastermind, Denzel Washington balances his heroic moments and his situational failures, Jodie Foster successfully contrasts Washington's straight-laced character with her shifty, sly role, Christopher Plummer provides the intrigue that makes us wonder what could be in his safe deposit box, and Willem Dafoe does exactly what you'd expect him to do in a gruff cop role.  The film makes for a great rewatch.  It has "The Sixth Sense" syndrome, where the twist blows your mind the first time but the film becomes a new experience with each subsequent watch as you catch more clues that you never realized were there.  "Inside Man" has some violence and swearing, but it is pretty tame for an R-rated film and worth watching for its complex story and rewarding twist.

In Inside Man, his first major screenplay, Russell Gewirtz has approached the classic heist screenplay by employing several novel variations on the genre. In addition to riffing on tropes within the heist genre, he utilizes a brazen theatricality in the modus operandi of the crew pulling off the job. The elegance of this device is not fully revealed to the viewer until the end of the story. Truly, some of the intricately layered trickery by Gewirtz can only be fully appreciated through consequent viewings. The effect of this gives the viewer not only a front row seat to an intricate chess match between the characters of Detective Keith Frazier and our protagonist and mastermind, Dalton Russell; it also allows us just enough information to pique our interest without giving much away in terms of payoff. (Gewirtz)
	In Save the Cat! The Last Book on Screenwriting You'll Ever Need, Blake Snyder dedicates a section of his book to defining not just genre types but also a deeper understanding of stories. At first blush, it may seem that Inside Man fulfills your run-of-the-mill Golden Fleece story. Snyder believes that, "the theme of every Golden Fleece movie is inner growth". (Snyder 27) Despite this, we are given a fully formed and completely capable protagonist in Dalton Russell. 
	From the opening image we are face-to-face with Dalton Russell, delivering a very cryptic and collusive speech directly to the camera. In Spike Lee's audio commentary, the director points out the use of his signature double-dolly camera rig to push perspective and focus onto the brick wall while maintaining audience attention on the information being dictated by the static Dalton Russell moving towards the wall. (Lee, Inside Man) In the big, third act reveal scene, we are given a repeat of this opening speech with the same camera move in reverse. The effect of the speechifying Dalton Russell telling us his exact plan gains new significance as we witness him behind the wall during his week of confinement. 
	I appreciated the Easter eggs that both Gewirtz and Lee sprinkled throughout the film and the screenplay. Gewirtz included multiple references to other films in the heist genre, including Dog Day Afternoon. Not to be outdone, Spike Lee followed that nod by casting two actors from Dog Day Afternoon.  During the pizza delivery/ bugging scene we get a double dose of nostalgia when the character delivering the pizzas is revealed as the same actor who delivered pizzas to Al Pacino in the aforementioned movie. (Lumet) On top of that, we are given a visual nod to one of Spike Lee's most critically acclaimed films as the pizzas delivered are from Sal's, the fictional pizzeria from Do the Right Thing. (Lee, Do the Right Thing - 20th Anniversary Edition)
	Aside from the phenomenal acting job done by the cast, I feel the combination of talents; Spike Lee, Russell Gewirtz, Brian Grazer and the great casting job done by Kim Coleman served the screenplay very well. Not only was it well executed on the screen, it was also a fascinating read. It revealed just enough in the opening image to whet my interest while the introduction of supporting characters throughout the screenplay was handled very deftly. I've watched the film three times and my appreciation of the depth of character and intelligence given to Clive Owen through the script continue to grow. From page to screen, it's been very rewarding to see Dalton Russell brought to life, in all his mastermind glory.

Inside Man is a heist film that makes the mistake of trying to be more than a heist film. Clive Owen makes a compelling criminal mastermind, and Denzel Washington is always great as a lead detective. You can easily see these two as formidable adversaries who are desperately trying to outthink one another. I loved how they intercut the interviews with the hostages in the aftermath of the crime with the events of the crime itself. It gave you some insight into how brilliant the crooks' plan was, and at the same time kept you guessing how it all ended. I do enjoy a good surprise ending as well, and I think this one would have been satisfying as well if it hadn't been spoiled for me in advance. Even knowing the twist of how they pulled off the heist, I think the movie could have held up. But, as I was saying, they made a critical mistake by trying to make this more than just a high-quality heist movie.

They throw in this entire storyline about the owner of the bank, and his desire to resolve the situation without letting his own secrets out. It's a pointless plot that seriously gets in the way of the film. Christopher Plummer is a brilliant actor, but he is so unnecessary to the plot of this movie. Then he hires a specialist played by Jodie Foster in one of the worst acting performances I've ever seen from a quality actress. Every time she comes on the screen the movie just stops in order to meander for awhile before getting back to the movie. Even worse is the fact that she, despite some big talk, proves herself to be absolutely terrible at what she does. Clive Owen is more in control of the situation than she is, and he's the crook! Then, of course, since Spike Lee is directing we have to make a point of throwing in some race relations. Sure it's a bank heist, but that doesn't mean we can't stop everything to watch the white cops jumping to racial stereotypes. If they had stuck with a pure bank heist film I think this could have been remarkable, but because they wasted half the movie I will never recommend Inside Man to anyone. They even diminished the twist ending by drowning it out with all these subplots wrapped up around it. Some focus and direction would have been nice.

Directed by Spike Lee, who started off making personal films about prejudice and race in America such as Do the Right Thing (1989), Jungle Fever (1991) and Malcolm X (1992). By the new millennium, he found it harder to get his brand of films made, but he got a hit when he decided to do this heist film written by Russell Gewirtz (Righteous Kill (2008)). It's a good thriller, but it requires attention. It begins when a group of workers dressed like painters walk into a bank in Manhattan, and take the customers and employees hostage. It's not long before the police get involved, and Detectives Keith Frazier (Denzel Washington) and Bill Mitchell (Chiwitel Ejiofor) take charge with the negotiations, meanwhile the bank's founder Arthur Case (Christopher Plummer) asks his fixer Madeleine White (Jodie Foster) to ensure the safety of the contents of a safe deposit box in the safe of the bank. The leader of the robbers, Dalton Russell (Clive Owen) has a much more bigger plan in mind, which he believes is the perfect robbery. It does feel a bit like Dog Day Afternoon (1975) at first, but there's a lot more to this film, and nothing is what it seems, and the pay-off, although it takes a while to get it, it well worth it. Lee has assembled a good cast, and he even plays around the the look and feel of the film as it unfolds.

With a stellar screenplay and strong vision, Inside Man presents a fine entry into the volume of heist films. Director Spike Lee is able to keep viewers in the dark just as long as our protagonist is, ratcheting up the tension as the hours go by. Denzel Washington delivers yet another strong leading role, as the voice of reason in a crazy situation, while Jodie Foster and Clive Owen play their roles in the whole shebang quite well. The soft ending may not deliver the immediate satisfaction of a gotcha moment a la Ocean's Eleven or The Italian Job, but the intellect of the story itself eliminates the need for one. This is not the joint you'd expect from Lee, but a welcome one nonetheless, and his choice of projects in the future will be scrutinized to see if he will continue down this more mainstream path.

The beginning felt disjointed, but when all the different characters started to meet each other and their storylines merged, what we get is a great drama with great acting, a well written script, and directing that pulls everything together. Even the music transforms from "typical action movie" music to a more jazzy film noir type music. Only points taken off are for the beginning feeling like a completely different movie. It felt like it didn't belong.

"Inside Man" is a clever heist film directed by Spike Lee, its full of surprises and is pretty satisfying.

His name is Dalton Russell (Clive Owen). Pay strict attention to what he says because he chooses his words carefully and he never repeats himself. I've told you his name, that's the "who". The "what" is a plan to execute the "perfect bank robbery". Why? Because he can and the only thing that can stop him is an ambitious hostage negotiator (Denzel Washington).

The script keeps you interested the whole time, it starts with a great opening scene that captivates your attention and just keeps the movie flowing right until the end. Clive Owen is brilliant as the mysterious bank robber and the pairing of Denzel Washington and Chiwetel Ejiofor as two buddy cops is hilarious (specially in the scene when they're interrogating a witness and can't stop staring at her boobs).

It has the multiculturalism of new york handled to its advantage, and like "Rashomon" it takes us from different points of view letting us choose what side of the story we're on. It has great twists in it and I love that it keeps it simple and never gets out of control.

Its a crowd pleaser (which is strange being directed by Spike Lee) that will have you singing "Chaiyya Chaiyya" by the time it ends.

The construction worker Kevin is played by talentless, over reaching and bravado oozing Al Palagonia who plays minor roles in most of Lee's films. Although he is a minor character I despise every time he shows up in his movies, especially knowing he gets the screen time for giving personal favors (Apollo Private Jets). Russel Gewirtz's script is picaresque on a scene to scene action basis but lacks any real meaning. The montage of possible outcomes when the police were planning on entering the bank was quite imaginative. The whole premise of the film relies on the final twist which is hardly a twist at all. The very ending is the most clever surprise that was in store and was actually a fortunate way to finalize the film The movie tries to be more then an action film but comes up short.

Spike Lee hadn't made a decent movie, sorry, "joint" in a while, so he was due.

A group of what appears to be painters enters a New York City Bank, and lock the doors. One of them then disables the security cameras with a flashlight equipped with an infrared light. 

They then reveal high-powered weapons, and ordering everybody on the ground. When they secure the place, they order all the adult hostages to strip down to their underwear, and put on clothing identical to their own. The strange thing is, they aren't interested in the vault. 

Two NYPD detectives are assigned to the case, and head to the scene to negotiate with the robbers/hostage takers. One of the detectives, played by Denzel Washington, believes that there is a lot more to the story than the villains are telling the authorities through released hostages. 

The bank's president (Christopher Plumber) has a secret in the bank that the hostage situation is taking place in, and to keep it secret he hires an independent negotiator (Jodie Foster) to go into the bank and put his secret into her hands to bring it out and away from the NYPD. 

There are some real strong performances in this movie. Washington is believable in his role as a police detective/hostage negotiator. Foster, who is not in the movie that much actually, also puts forth a strong performance. In fact, the entire cast is good. 

The script was strong, and interesting, although I think there may have been some plot holes. The flashback and interrogation scenes helped advance the story nicely. 

The soundtrack was pretty unique. To me, many of the songs appeared to have African influences. There were no classic tunes everybody knows, and no annoyingly catchy songs that you'll be humming for a week after seeing the movie. 

There are numerous twists in this film that are spread out just enough so you will notice them. Spike Lee did a very good job with everything in the direction of this movie.

Another Classic Tail where Denzel is a Hostage Negotiator.

A bank robbery in New York has gotten out of control, and it's up to police detective Keith Frazier (Denzel Washington) to act as hostage negotiator and get the bank personal and customers out safely before things turn even worse than they already are. This turns out to be a tough case, since the leader of the bank robbers, Dalton Russell (Clive Owen), turns out to be a very smart individual, who has everything planned to perfection, and who throws up surprise after surprise for Frazier and his men. But while the people around Frazier are slowly getting more and more nervous, he himself does not lose his mind, and begins a high stakes battle of wits with Russell. Things are further complicated, however, when the mayor of New York introduces a mysterious woman to Frazier. This woman (Jodie Foster) wants to protect something that is hidden in one of the safety deposit boxes inside the bank, and she will stop at nothing to force Frazier to let her inside the bank and make sure nothing happens to the contents.
This all sounds like an intriguing premise for a thriller, but the movie goes a few steps further than just having an interesting plot. Because while Inside Man does hit all the right notes when it comes to keeping you guessing about what is really going on, it is also very successful in mixing the grittier moments with comedy elements. At times, Inside Man is very funny, but in a way that does not deflate the tension. The dialogue is sharp, with the conversations between Frazier and Russell being especially fascinating, and both actors are at the top of their game in this new movie. Washington's Frazier is an intense but laconic individual, who has a permanent smirk on his face but who reads the bank robbers intentions better than anybody else, while Owen is charismatic and fascinating as the mastermind behind the bank robbery. I was a little disappointed however with Jodie Foster's role. While her part is potentially fascinating, she does not really get the chance to do anything with it other than look cool and act tough. Yes, we all know that she is very good at that, but with a bit more background story, and a bit more screen time, her part could have been even more interesting.
With Inside Man, Lee showcases an interesting way of directing thrillers. He ignores the usual build up that you see in thrillers, which consists of an introduction, a chronological development of the main intrigue, followed by a final act in which everything is wrapped up neatly (even flashing forward several times, thus revealing some important developments before they have happened), and this only serves to make Inside Man a movie that is more than your regular suspense movie. I enjoyed this original approach very much, even though he does take quite a long time to wrap things up at the end.
